▿ Step
  ResponseEnded

▿ Request
  GET http://localhost:8080/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions
  Authorization: Basic aGVsbG86d29ybGQ=

  (Data, 0 bytes)

▿ Response
  Status 200 OK
  Content-Length: 28760
  Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8

832px){.d-mb0{margin-bottom:0}.d-mb1{margin-bottom:0.5rem}.d-mb2{margin-bottom:1rem}.d-mb3{margin-bottom:2rem}.d-mb4{margin-bottom:4rem}.d-ml0{margin-left:0}.d-ml1{margin-left:0.5rem}.d-ml2{margin-left:1rem}.d-ml3{margin-left:2rem}.d-ml4{margin-left:4rem}.d-mr0{margin-right:0}.d-mr1{margin-right:0.5rem}.d-mr2{margin-right:1rem}.d-mr3{margin-right:2rem}.d-mr4{margin-right:4rem}.d-mt0{margin-top:0}.d-mt1{margin-top:0.5rem}.d-mt2{margin-top:1rem}.d-mt3{margin-top:2rem}.d-mt4{margin-top:4rem}}@media only screen and (min-width: 832px){.sticky-d{position:sticky;position:-webkit-sticky}}</style><style></style><meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1.0"><script>(function(i,s,o,g,r,a,m){i['GoogleAnalyticsObject']=r;i[r]=i[r]||function(){(i[r].q=i[r].q||[]).push(arguments)},i[r].l=1*new Date();a=s.createElement(o),m=s.getElementsByTagName(o)[0];a.async=1;a.src=g;m.parentNode.insertBefore(a,m)})(window,document,'script','https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js','ga');ga('create', 'UA-106218876-1', 'auto');ga('send', 'pageview');</script><link rel="stylesheet" href="//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/highlight.js/9.12.0/styles/github.min.css"><script src="//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/highlight.js/9.12.0/highlight.min.js"></script><script>hljs.initHighlightingOnLoad();</script></head><body><div class=" row"><div class=" col-m col-m-12 col-d-7"><div><div class="m-pl4 m-pr4 m-pt4 m-pb4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 1</strong><h1 class="fg-black bold h4 lh-2 m-mt0"><a href="/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions">Proof in Functions</a></h1><p class="fg-black normal h5 lh-4">Swift’s generic functions allow us to explore a beautiful idea that straddles the line between mathematics and computer science. In this episode we explore how we can use Swift’s type system to prove mathematical theorems, and show how this opens the doors to having the compiler verify properties of your program.</p></div><hr class="pf-divider border-top m-ml0 m-mr0 m-mt0 m-mb0 bg-white"><div class="m-pl4 m-pr4 m-pt4 m-pb4 bg-white"><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="0" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:00</a>Swift’s generic functions allow us to explore a beautiful idea that straddles the line between mathematics and computer science. If you write down and implement a function using only generic data types, there is a corresponding mathematical theorem that you have proven true. There are a lot of pieces to that statement, but by the end of this short article you will understand what that means, and we will have constructed a computer proof of De Morgan’s law.</p><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="30" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:30</a>All of the code samples in this article are contained in a Swift playground available for download here.</p><h2 class="h4 lh-3 m-pt2">Generic Functions</h2><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="30" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:30</a>Let’s start with some exercises to prepare our brains for this kind of thinking. If someone handed you the following function declaration, which doesn’t currently compile, and asked you to fill it out so that it compiles, could you?</p><pre><code class="code block m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 overflow-auto-x swift">func f &lt;A&gt; (x: A) -&gt; A {
    ???
  }</code></pre><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="30" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:30</a>It’s a function that takes an x in some type A (can be any type) and needs to return something in A. We have absolutely no knowledge of A. No way of constructing a value in that type. For example, we can’t even do something like A() to construct a value, for we have no way of knowing if A has an initializer of that form. Even worse, there’s a chance that A cannot be instantiated, i.e. A has no values! For example, an enum with no cases cannot be instantiated:</p><pre><code class="code block m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 overflow-auto-x swift">enum Empty {
    // no cases!
  }</code></pre><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="30" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:30</a>This type is valid and compiles just fine, but no instance of it can ever be created. Kind of bizarre, but it will be useful later. Some languages call this type Bottom (⊥).</p><p><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="30" class="vid-time-link text-decoration-none bg-gray650 pf-link-white rounded h6">00:30</a>So, back to that function f. How can we implement it so that the compiler says everything is A-Ok? Well, we really have no choice but to just return x, i.e. it’s the identity function:</p></div></div></div><div class="bg-dark first-m last-d col-m col-m-12 col-d-5"><div class="sticky-d top-0"><video class="fit" controls playsinline autoplay poster=""><source src="https://www.videvo.net/videvo_files/converted/2017_08/videos/170724_15_Setangibeach.mp486212.mp4"></video><div class="m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pt4 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pb0"><h6 class="fg-black bold h6 lh-1 caps fg-gray850 m-pb1">Chapters</h6><div class="m-mb1 row"><div class=" col-m col-m-10"><div><a href="" onclick="javascript:var video = document.getElementsByTagName(&quot;video&quot;)[0];
  video.currentTime = event.target.dataset.t;
  video.play();
  event.preventDefault();" data-t="60" class="pf-link-green text-decoration-none">Generic Functions</a></div></div><div class=" col-m col-m-2"><div class="fg-purple end-align opacity-75">01:00</div></div></div></div><div class="bg-dark hide-m"><div class="m-pt3 m-pl4 m-pr4"><h6 class="fg-black bold h6 lh-1 caps fg-gray850 m-pb1">Downloads</h6><img alt="" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " class="align-middle" width="20" height="20"><a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco/episode-code-samples/tree/master/ep1-proof-in-functions" class="pf-link-yellow m-ml1 align-middle">ep1-proof-in-functions.playground</a></div><div class="m-pl4 m-pr4 m-pt3 m-pb3"><h6 class="fg-black bold h6 lh-1 caps fg-gray850 m-pb1">Credits</h6><p class="fg-gray850">Hosted by <a class="pf-link-white" href="mailto:brandon@pointfree.co">Brandon&nbsp;Williams</a> and <a class="pf-link-white" href="mailto:stephen@pointfree.co">Stephen&nbsp;Celis</a>. Recorded in Brooklyn, NY.</p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="bg-dark hide-d"><div class="m-pt3 m-pl4 m-pr4"><h6 class="fg-black bold h6 lh-1 caps fg-gray850 m-pb1">Downloads</h6><img alt="" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64, " class="align-middle" width="20" height="20"><a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco/episode-code-samples/tree/master/ep1-proof-in-functions" class="pf-link-yellow m-ml1 align-middle">ep1-proof-in-functions.playground</a></div><div class="m-pl4 m-pr4 m-pt3 m-pb3"><h6 class="fg-black bold h6 lh-1 caps fg-gray850 m-pb1">Credits</h6><p class="fg-gray850">Hosted by <a class="pf-link-white" href="mailto:brandon@pointfree.co">Brandon&nbsp;Williams</a> and <a class="pf-link-white" href="mailto:stephen@pointfree.co">Stephen&nbsp;Celis</a>. Recorded in Brooklyn, NY.</p></div></div><footer class="row m-pl3 m-pr3 m-pt3 m-pb3 d-pl4 d-pr4 d-pt4 d-pb4 bg-black"><div class=" col-m col-m-12 col-d-6"><div class="m-pb2 d-pr4"><h4 class="fg-black bold h4 lh-2 m-mb0"><a href="/home" class="pf-link-white">Point-Free</a></h4><p class="fg-black normal h5 lh-4 fg-white">A weekly video series on functional programming and the Swift programming language.
